data.title: Absence and Elimination: Madhyamaka Interpretation in the Formation of Scholastic Traditions in Tibet
data.abstractNote:
Abstract 
             
              This paper examines early Tibetan authors’ treatment of “elimination” ( 
              viccheda/vyavaccheda 
              ), in order to trace competing lines of Madhyamaka exegesis. I compare Gyamarwa’s ( 
              rgya dmar ba byang chub grags 
              ; twelfth century) treatment of this topic in his 
              Analysis of the Essence of Madhyamaka 
              with that of his teacher Gangpa Sheu ( 
              gangs pa she’u 
              ) and four early Tibetan Prāsaṅgika authors. I conclude that Gyamarwa knew of Candrakīrti’s Madhyamaka from Atiśa’s followers, but prioritized utilizing Śāntideva’s and Jñānagarbha’s views to support his Madhyamaka position. I reflect further on the nature of “tradition” in early Tibetan scholasticism, focusing on Sangpu Neutok ( 
              gsang phu ne’u thog 
              ) Monastery.
data.publicationTitle: Journal of South Asian Intellectual History
